title: Solinas prime
summary: In mathematics, a Solinas prime, or generalized Mersenne prime, is a prime number that has the form f ( 2 m ) {\displaystyle f(2^{m})} , where f ( x ) {\displaystyle f(x)} is a low-degree polynomial with small integer coefficients.[1][2] These primes allow fast modular reduction algorithms and are widely used in cryptography. They are named after Jerome Solinas.
